audio_description: Hello foodies, welcome to Wish My Food! Today’s special is Tamil Nadu’s famous Ambur Chicken Dum Biryani. This is a traditional Muslim recipe from Ambur, a town in Tamil Nadu. It’s rich in flavor and very spicy and tasty. The best part is that both the chicken and rice are cooked together in dum (steam). So, there’s no issue like undercooked chicken or hard rice.

actions: Placing fried rice onto a banana leaf
Adding ginger garlic paste to the pot
Adding ground chili paste to the pot
Mixing the pastes with the contents in the pot
Adding chicken pieces to the bowl
Frying chicken until lightly golden brown
Stirring the chicken mixture every 3 minutes
Adding sliced tomatoes to the pot
Adding sliced red and green bell peppers to the pot
Adding slit green chilies to the pot
Pouring whisked curd into the pot
Pouring whisked curd into the pot
Adding caramel masala to the pot
Stirring the contents of the pot
Removing the lid to check the curry
Adding fresh cilantro to chicken curry
Adding soaked rice to the pot
Stirring the pot with the slotted spoon
Placing a lid on the pot
Placing a water bowl near the cooking pot
Placing a bowl in the pot
Watching as the mixture cooks for 20 minutes
Placing the lid on the pot
Adding chopped coriander and mint to the rice
Stirring the contents of the pot
Placing rice on a banana leaf
Piling rice on the banana leaf
Placing lemon wedge on the serving dish
Placing a portion of sauce in a separate bowl
Arranging sliced onions beside the dish
Serving meat and sauce onto rice

audio_description: Every time, it turns out to be a super hit recipe. Let’s start. First, take 2 cups (approx. 185g per cup) of Jeera rice. Add fennel seeds along with the rice. Wash the rice thoroughly once and soak it for some time, so that the aroma is retained.

audio_description: In Ambur Chicken Biryani, the spice comes from red chilies alone. You need to use dried red chilies. Break them and soak them slightly. If you don’t have stone mortar, you can use a mixer.

audio_description: Once it starts frying well, add 2 teaspoons of coriander powder. When the oil starts separating, add 1 kg of chicken cut into medium pieces. Cook until the chicken turns golden brown on medium flame.

audio_description: It takes about 15 minutes for the chicken to get half-cooked. Always remember, after cleaning the chicken, it should remain inside the marinade for at least 30 minutes. That’s when chicken cooks perfectly during dum. Even chicken shop people know this.

audio_description: Once cooked, add 3 chopped tomatoes, 3 slit green chilies, enough salt, ½ cup (about 125 ml) whisked curd, 1½ tablespoons garam masala, and 1 cup (250 ml) water. Mix everything well.

audio_description: Into another pot, add 3 tablespoons of salt. Add the soaked rice into boiling water. Also, add 2 teaspoons of oil. Cook the rice up to 80% only. Everyone knows what 80% cooked rice looks like.

audio_description: After that, pour the reserved gravy over the rice. Then add the leftover rice water (starch water) over the biryani. Seal the pot with a lid and cook on low flame for 20 minutes.

audio_description: After 20 minutes, check – it will look perfect. No need to do anything else. This is the perfect texture. At this stage, add 2 tablespoons of ghee, a little chopped coriander and mint, mix gently, and fluff the biryani slowly.

audio_description: If it's crumbly, it’s like Hyderabadi biryani. But in Tamil Nadu biryani, the rice is softer. It should be soft enough to hold in a spoon without breaking. That’s the texture expected here.
